At the 2006 Narrative Conference my contribution to the Wayne Booth Panel was entitled "Attendant Intentions: Reading with Booth's Concept of the Implied Author." A revised and expanded version of that paper was presented with the current title, "Fiction as Restriction," at "Passion and New Ethics: A Symposium on Novel Studies," hosted by Princeton University (November 2006).

"Why Ethical Criticism," Booth provides a brief summary of his position: "It is from such disagreements that the most productive literary criticism can emerge. When undertaken seriously, neither side is likely to feel fully victorious. Both sides will have learned something overlooked, either about the work itself or about the world of ethical values in which we all live. And both sides, whether in reading the work or discussing it, are undergoing the ethical growth that serious encounters with such conflict can pro- duce" (27, my emphasis)
